content.title: Arty stay at the Deep Ellum Hostel

introduction.small: Among the street art frescoes and microbreweries of Dallas' hipster neighbourhood, Deep Ellum Hostel asserts its charm amid a historic building.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Arty stay at the Deep Ellum Hostel

paragraphs.text:
Saloon, syrup factory, repair shop… The building at the corner of Elm Street and North Crowdus Street, near the city centre of Dallas, has lived several lives. Its last rebirth took the shape of an inn, the only one of the Texan city. Between the highlighting of century-old architectural details, exposed brick walls and a staircase adorned with old cement tiles, the charm of this historic building has been perfectly preserved. Travelling families or groups of friends will choose rooms with bunk beds made of old natural wood. Others looking for more privacy will favour separate bedrooms, showcasing carefully selected vintage decoration. At the heart of the lively Deep Ellum neighbourhood, hotspot of the art scene and nightlife, Deep Ellum Hostel also offers a tapas bar named Izkina (“corner” in Basque language). At night, all you will have to do to enjoy a few pintxos and Spanish wines (in moderation, of course) is to find the entrance: near the front desk, look for a discreet doorway, made of piled-up suitcases.

Deep Ellum Hostel
2801 Elm Street
Dallas, TX 75226

Tel: +1 214 712 8118

www.deepellumhostel.com

Rooms: bed from 35 USD, private bedrooms from 109 USD

content.title: Armoury D.E., plug into creative cooking

introduction.small: In the heart of Dallas' most trendy neighbourhood, embark on an eclectic gustatory journey in an underground atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Armoury D.E., plug into creative cooking

paragraphs.text:
Do you like the alternative and artsy side of the Deep Ellum district? Check out its culinary options too. Particularly renowned for its nocturnal atmosphere, the bar-restaurant Armoury D.E. is unanimously acclaimed for its imaginative menu with excellent value. Inside, the large exposed brick walls and the bar of a thousand bottles overhung by a fresco are in keeping with the neighbourhood vibe. Here, you can order a homemade beer, but don't miss on one of the tasty cocktails like the Mr. Pink, mixing absinthe, gin and raspberries—said to be one of the ten most original drinks in the city. Nearby, wooden tables and blue benches invite you to enjoy eclectic cooking: spätzle, chicken paprika, grilled octopus, burgers. The kitchen stays open until 2 a.m., but if you are not a night owl and want to enjoy Deep Ellum on Sunday morning, Armoury D. E. also welcomes you for a delicious brunch. The French Toast is a must!

Armoury D.E.
2714 Elm Street
Dallas, TX 75226

+1 972 803 5151

www.armouryde.com

Menu: about 15 USD

content.title: San Antonio, the “Little Venice” of Texas

introduction.small: Home to the famous siege during the Texan struggle against the Mexicans, visitors can choose from many attractions today, including a walk among the canals.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: San Antonio, the “Little Venice” of Texas

paragraphs.text:
Discovered by a Spanish expedition in 1691 on the name day of St. Antonio of Padua, from whom it takes its name, San Antonio is a multi-faceted city. History meets modernity, in the city's architecture where baroque buildings such as San Fernando Cathedral are found side-by-side with the city's modern structures, as well as in a plethora of tourist attractions. Visit Fort Alamo, the famous Spanish mission where Davy Crockett and his companions resisted the Mexican army to later declare the independence of the state of Texas.
San Antonio is also famous for its river, which flows through its centre in the form of several canals—earning the city the nickname of the “Little Venice” of Texas. You will love the River Walk, lined with cafes and shops along several kilometres of trails to walk, hike or bike.
The San Antonio Museum of Art, one of the most important museums in Texas, offers a wide variety of items and works of art, from ancient Egypt to the present day. Don't miss the McNay Art Museum as well. Housed in the former residence of the collector Marion Koogler McNay, this museum is worth the detour for its collection of everything from medieval and Renaissance art, to Southwestern prints and drawings—including several by McNay herself.

San Antonio Museum of Art
200 West Jones Avenue
San Antonio, TX 78215
Tel : +1 210 978 8100
www.samuseum.org

McNay Art Museum
6000 North New Braunfels Avenue
San Antonio, TX 78209
Tel : +1 210 824 5368
www.mcnayart.org

content.title: Margarita Mile, the best Margarita in Dallas

introduction.small: Thanks to this refreshing app, visitors access a surprising selection of margarita spots throughout the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Margarita Mile, the best Margarita in Dallas

paragraphs.text: In 1971, a young Dallas resident named Mariano Martinez dreamed up a revolutionary new machine to make Frozen Margarita—an invention now on display at the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History in Washington. Since 2018, a new innovation has become available, an original way to discover an infinite variety of margaritas—always in moderation. You can download the refreshing free application “The Margarita Mile” to plan your evening itinerary. With an interactive map, you can choose between the best trendy bars that serve this famous drink. Directions, drink menus, special offers, games and quizzes are some of the multiple options on the app. Your thirst (for discovery) will lead you from classics to more original creations—frozen or on the rocks, with jalapeño peppers or liquid nitrogen, unless you opt for the masterful Frozen Rimy Rita made from Dulce Vida Lime tequila, raspberry liqueur, Cointreau and a sangria popsicle. Margaritas in all shapes and sizes.

content.title: Klyde Warren Park, named after a billionaire's son

introduction.small: Recent, practical and attractive, this urban green space is the pride of Dallas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Klyde Warren Park, named after a billionaire's son

paragraphs.text:
You dreamed of a refreshing pause between two visits? You will find a great place for a break in Klyde Warren Park, named after the young son of billionaire Kelcy Warren. Ideally located at the intersection of Downtown, Uptown and the Arts District, this two-hectare green space, opened in 2012, was built above the underground section of the Woodall Rodgers Freeway. Dallas residents immediately fell in love with this green space and come to relax during the day on the huge rectangular lawn or under the trees. Children love playing in the many playgrounds and adults take yoga classes or even Zumba (a mix of Latin dance and fitness) near the Muse Family Performance Pavilion. The park also hosts concerts and theatre performances throughout the year. Head to the Nancy Collins Fisher Pavilion for a bite to eat. You can enjoy your meal or snack on the grass with an excellent view of the Dallas skyscrapers.

Klyde Warren Park
2012 Woodall Rodgers Fwy
Dallas, TX 75201

+1 214 716 4500

www.klydewarrenpark.org

content.title: Fort Worth, cowboy culture like nowhere else

introduction.small: The West starts here: with rodeos, cattle drives and saloons. Put your cowboy hat on and pull on your boots and spurs!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fort Worth, cowboy culture like nowhere else

paragraphs.text:
West of Dallas is the city where the myth of the Texas cowboy begins. Located right on the famous Chisholm Trail, Fort Worth, then nicknamed “Cowtown”, was the last stop before entering Indian territory and the only route to transport cattle from Texas ranches to railway stations up North. Now a tourist area, Fort Worth will take you on a trip back in time. Ode to the Old West, the Fort Worth Stockyards district has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places since 1976. Admire the Cowtown Coliseum, an arena built in 1908, where rodeos are still held, and head to Billy Bob's Texas, the largest honky tonk (a typical country and western nightclub) in all 50 states, which brings thousands of cowboys together every weekend to enjoy country dancing. Watch the Texas Longhorns pass by in a mini-cattle drive with Fort Worth Herd and, if you are a true country music fan, stop off at Chief Records. Don't miss the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth, which houses nearly 3,000 works by some modern masters (Pablo Picasso, Mark Rothko and Andy Warhol).

Cowtown Coliseum
121 East Exchange Avenue
Fort Worth, TX 76164
Tel : +1 817 625 1025
www.fortworthstockyards.org/play/cowtown-coliseum

Billy Bob's Texas
2520 Rodeo Plaza
Fort Worth, TX 76164
Tel : +1 817 624 7117
www.billybobstexas.com

Ernest Tubb Record Shop
140 East Exchange Avenue #135
Fort Worth, TX 76164
Tel : +1 817 624 8449
www.etrecordshop.com

Museum of Modern Art of Fort Worth
3200 Darnell Street
Fort Worth, Texas 76107
Tel : +1 817 738 9215
www.themodern.org

content.title: Retro Dallas at The Belmont

introduction.small: This “boutique motel”, now an institution, invites you to jump back to the 1950s.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Retro Dallas at The Belmont

paragraphs.text:
The authentic retro look of the Belmont will lull you inside. Located in the Bishop Arts District and far from the hustle and bustle of the city, yet only three kilometres away, this historic hotel showcases a rounded white facade characteristic of the 1950s. Designed by architect Charles Stevens Dilbeck, it combines the privilege of history with contemporary elegance, having recently been completely renovated. The Belmont now serves a trendy clientele in search of a relaxed ambiance and in need of comfort. In total, 64 classic rooms, suites and bungalows separated by charming patios, each with a table and a few chairs. Ask for the Terrace Suite, which private terrace offers an incomparable view of Dallas. Enjoy the vintage white-tiled bathrooms, bath tubs, furniture and 1950s kitchenettes, in short, an authentic atmosphere, without any fuss. In the evening, the pool lights up as the city's hipsters gather at the bar.

The Belmont
901 Fort Worth Avenue
Dallas, TX 75208

+1 214 421 4500

www.belmontdallas.com/

Rooms: from 100 USD

content.title: Austin, live music capital of the world

introduction.small: “Keep Austin Weird”, the unofficial slogan of independent businesses in the capital, evokes the strong character and alternative side of a city that lives to the rhythm of music.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Austin, live music capital of the world

paragraphs.text:
This city of a million people located inland on the edge of the Hill Country region is not only Texas' Silicon Valley, renowned for its high technology. A true hot spot for blues and country music since the 1970s, Austin is a real stronghold of countless festivities as well, where all music genres are played throughout 250 venues, not to mention bars and clubs. Stroll along the old-fashioned facades of 6th Street and you'll see a colourful crowd—cowboys, businessmen, hippies and hipsters. Near Rainey Street, just a stone's throw from the city centre, an old residential area has become a meeting point since the renovation of its bungalows—now full of cocktail bars and lounges, complete with backyards. Every March since 1987, Austin has been hosting South by Southwest (SXSW), one of the world's most renowned festivals celebrating the convergence of music, film and interactive media. Austin, you rock!

www.sxsw.com

www.austintexas.org

content.title: Presidential Center, in the shoes of George W. Bush

introduction.small: How about a visit to the Oval Office or a glimpse of the gala clothes of the First Lady? You can see both in the archives of the eight-year Bush presidency.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Presidential Center, in the shoes of George W. Bush

paragraphs.text:
“This will always be a place that welcomes each visitor with open arms.” In her own way, Laura Bush, the wife of the former U.S. President, sums up the spirit that animates the library of the presidential centre. In addition to archives and a conference centre, this solemn building, opened in 2013 with an area of 100,000 m2, contains the George W. Bush Institute. Meander through the Presidential Library where you can explore the years of the Bush presidency (2001 to 2009). Nestled among thousands of documents and photos, a few unusual objects will catch your eye, such as the red telephone connecting the White House to the Kremlin or a few signed baseballs. You will discover the exact replica of the Oval Office under the Bush presidency as well as the reconstruction of the West Wing. Giving onto an outdoor space inspired by the White House rose garden, called the “Texas Rose Garden”, it offers a pleasant conclusion to this very enriching walk.

George W. Bush Presidential Center
2943 SMU Boulevard
Dallas, TX 75205

+1 214 200 4300

www.bushcenter.org

content.title: Foxyco, meat grilled over a wood fire near the riverfront

introduction.small: Opened in September 2018 and advertising “Modern American cuisine”, this trendy restaurant on the riverfront is part of the Design District.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Foxyco, meat grilled over a wood fire near the riverfront

paragraphs.text:
By all accounts, this is the place to be. From the Trinity River warehouses to the Design District buildings, Foxyco's floor-to-ceiling picture windows offer a breathtaking view of Downtown Dallas. Along the walls painted in Jackson Pollock style, the 1950s furniture flanked by designer lighting fixtures are in keeping with the style. However, don't be surprised to find the grill right in front of the open kitchen. Jon Stevens, the owner, has made wood-fired grilling his signature. His mantra: “smoked and salted”! Alongside his wife, he has chosen to revolutionise traditional Texan cuisine by adding a more sophisticated touch. Foxy's “co” refers to the other part of the menu, with unexpected dishes: a wide choice of appetizers (grilled artichokes or Wagyu meatballs) will give you time to choose the main course. Indulge in lamb chops served with smashed garlic and mint potatoes, or balsamic vinegar beef Bolognese with ricotta gnocchi. You won't be disappointed.

Foxyco
921 North Riverfront Boulevard #300
Dallas, TX 75207

+1 214 295 5532

foxycodallas.com

Menu: about 28 USD

content.title: Dallas Arts District, the largest American neighbourhood for the arts

introduction.small: Far from a cultural desert, the Dallas artistic centre has many surprises in store for you, including a 27-hectare district where you can travel through the art world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dallas Arts District, the largest American neighbourhood for the arts

paragraphs.text:
This Texas city is bursting with energy. Sponsored by Fort Worth's major livestock breeders, oil magnates, captains of industry and cotton moguls, Dallas' ambition is to become a major artistic capital in the United States, alongside New York, Miami and Los Angeles. The Dallas Arts District, located north of the city centre, includes five renowned art museums and performance halls such as the Dallas Theater Center. This architectural complex houses several buildings designed by leading architects: Renzo Piano, I. M. Pei, Rem Koolhaas and Joshua Prince-Ramus. The Dallas Museum of Art (DMA) offers more than 24,000 works of art from the Third millennium BC to the present day, and the Kimbell Art Museum's exquisite collection of European, Asian and pre-Columbian works are impressively exhibited with unique lighting techniques. The Amon Carter Museum with an impressive collection of artists from the 1950s also has a library of more than 150,000 items. Finally, the amazing Nasher Sculpture Center, exhibits modern masterpieces that express love and knowledge of the art at its finest.

Dallas Theater Center
2400 Flora Street
Dallas, TX 75201
Tel : +1 214 880 0202
www.dallastheatercenter.org

Dallas Museum of Art
1717 North Harwood Street
Dallas, TX 75201
Tel : +1 214 922 1200
www.dma.org

Kimbell Art Museum
3333 Camp Bowie Blvd
Fort Worth, TX 76107
Tel : +1 817 332 8451
www.kimbellart.org

Amon Carter Museum
3501 Camp Bowie Boulevard
Fort Worth, TX 76107
Tel : +1 817 738 1933
www.cartermuseum.org

Nasher Sculpture Center
2001 Flora Street, Dallas
Dallas, TX 75201
Tel : +1 214 242 5100
www.nashersculpturecenter.org

content.title: Sachet, the vegetable hotspot

introduction.small: Dallas locals rush here for the veggies! Colourful Mediterranean cuisine as delicious as it is healthy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sachet, the vegetable hotspot

paragraphs.text:
In Dallas, satisfying a need for vegetables may be a bit of a challenge, as steak houses dominate the restaurant scene. With its name inscribed in elegant gold letters on the outside entrance, Sachet is a real gem, and a green one at that. Of the roughly 50 dishes on the menu, only about 15 include meat. Instead, vegetables are the stars—local, seasonal and irreproachably traceable. A bet that works, as Sachet has constantly been full since it opened in January 2018.
The minimalist decor accents the original menu. The windows are wide, the white room spacious and bright, crossed in its centre by a huge bar in light wood with wicker seating. Round tables and more intimate booths are spread throughout the restaurant. Along with falafels, squid with fennel and tortiglioni, the mezzes are presented in 20 attractive varieties. Pistachios and Marcona almonds, spiced with lemon and rosemary, are a must, as well as spicy tabbouleh with carrots and parsley. You can add some starters, tapas, salads, pasta, seafood and meat to complete your meal.

Sachet
4270 Oak Lawn Avenue
Dallas, TX 75219

+1 214 613 6425

www.sachetdallas.com

Menu: about 40 USD

content.title: New artistic hangouts, some of the best kept secrets in Dallas

introduction.small: The Deep Ellum and Bishop Arts Districts, The Power Station or The Warehouse... Dallas overflows with trendy spots.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: New artistic hangouts, some of the best kept secrets in Dallas

paragraphs.text:
Just like in Brooklyn's Williamsburg, coolness abounds in these former industrial sites reinvented as art districts, replete with street art, concept stores and converted warehouses full of galleries and bars.
A cradle for jazz and blues and in full rebirth since 2010, Deep Ellum is the official name of this district—after the local pronunciation of Deep Elm Street was adopted. The area showcases small brick buildings, graffitied walls, tattoo parlours, barbershops, drugstores, trendy thrift shops and live music venues to “discover music, explore art and expect the unexpected”.
Not far away, The Power Station, a former transformer of the Dallas Power & Light Company, is now an experimental and contemporary art space. Three times a year, young artists have carte blanche to produce their creations. In the hippie-suffused historical Bishop Arts District, southwest of the city centre, check out the coffee shops, bookstores, art galleries, independent stores and “Made in Texas” cider tastings. The Warehouse Dallas, on the way, is a 2,000 m² modern art gallery opened in 2012 on the outskirts of Downtown Dallas, where the exceptional contemporary works and exhibitions rival major museums.

The Power Station
3816 Commerce Street
Dallas, TX 75226
Tel +1 214 827 0163
www.powerstationdallas.com

The Warehouse Dallas
14105 Inwood Road
Dallas, TX 75244
Tel : +1 214 442 2872
www.thewarehousedallas.org

content.title: Billy Can Can, eat in a 19th-century saloon!

introduction.small: “Delicious!” is what you will utter after eating one of the typical Texan dishes served in this modern saloon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Billy Can Can, eat in a 19th-century saloon!

paragraphs.text:
The black brick front, huge picture windows and the name of the restaurant, with its striking syllables, all evoke the wild American West. To discover the spice of old-fashioned Texas restaurants with a modern touch, nothing beats the Billy Can Can. Opened in 2018 near Victory Park, this restaurant welcomes its many customers to a spacious room in a friendly setting. Behind the many round tables with high chairs stands a huge wooden bar. Order a drink and it will be served with a game-card shaped coaster—a nod to the saloon theme. But here, there is no cheap alcohol or bad manners, even if vivacity is encouraged. The chef, an alumnus of the Joule Hotel, offers a menu that succeeds in bridging the gap between traditional and contemporary cuisine. Fried oysters with pepper sauce, winter squash ravioli or Nashville chicken, whatever your choice may be, it's all good!

Billy Can Can
2386 Victory Park Lane
Dallas, TX 75219

+1 214 296 2610

www.billycancan.com

Menu: about 56 USD

content.title: AT&T Stadium, the world's largest covered stadium

introduction.small: Home to the famous Dallas Cowboys, this technological triumph is dedicated to the glory of American football.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: AT&T Stadium, the world's largest covered stadium

paragraphs.text:
This super stadium hosts major events such as the 2010 Super Bowl— the National Football League championship game. This giant structure set in Arlington, near the Rangers Ballpark, is sided with 91-metre high arches, and a half-metal, half-glass facade that catches the reflecting sun. The retractable roof of almost 202,000 m2, according to some, lets God “watch the Cowboys on Sunday”.
The stadium was completely renovated in 2009, with luxurious interior design and giant screens at a cost of more than a billion dollars. With a capacity of more than 100,000 people, the AT&T Stadium will hopefully be the scene of a new Super Bowl in the coming years. Parking around the stadium is prohibitively expensive, so choose public transit to get there instead. The Metro Arlington Xpress (MAX) bus system or the shuttle bus bring you in from the city centre. An unforgettable place to see a game or concert.

AT&T Stadium
1 AT&T Way
Arlington, TX 76011

+1 817 892 4000

www.attstadium.com

content.title: Zero Gravity Thrill Amusement Park for strong emotions

introduction.small: Free fall or giant swing… jump into the void or fly up into space at one of the best amusement parks in Dallas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zero Gravity Thrill Amusement Park for strong emotions

paragraphs.text:
Take a deep breath before you scream! For more than 20 years now, the Zero Gravity Thrill Amusement Park has been a source of intense emotions, a mere ten minutes by car from downtown. Thrill-seekers will get their fix here with an indescribable mixture of fear and pleasure. Between serious bungee-jumping sessions, the Skycoaster, and the Texas Blastoff, there is no shortage of extreme rides. The most surprising might be “Nothing but Net” for budding stuntmen, consisting of an unassisted freefall without a harness that lets you fall into a huge net. Rest assured, you are under the constant supervision of professionals. Moreover, the slogan of the Zero Gravity Thrill Amusement Park is “Safety first”!

Zero Gravity Thrill Amusement Park
11131 Malibu Drive
Dallas, TX 75229

+1 972 484 8359

www.gojump.com

content.title: Perot Museum, a journey to the centre of the Earth

introduction.small: Feeding a dinosaur, experiencing an earthquake or visiting an FBI lab—some great options await you at this very popular interactive museum!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Perot Museum, a journey to the centre of the Earth

paragraphs.text:
Designed by Thom Mayne, 2005 winner of the Pritzker Prize for Architecture, this rough-hewn cube evokes the harshness of the Texas plains. The surprising exterior, located in the heart of the city centre, contains an unusual and enriching itinerary covering more than 16,000 m2 over five floors. Educational games, interactive kiosks, laboratories, as well as an auditorium surround you with new technologies—videos, tablets, 3D and more. From the human body to the planet Earth, from the forces of nature to fossils, every possible topic is covered in this museum devoted to nature and science. You will witness the explosion of the Big Bang, fly like a bird, make giant waves and discover the blood vessels that run throughout our bodies. If you are wondering about the origins of the universe, pause in the Expanding Universe Hall. Since 2013, the museum has continually been adding new digital edutainment activities in both English and Spanish. A museum of the future and a living lesson in engineering, technology and conservation for kids and adults! Plan at least two hours for your visit; free entry once a month.

Perot Museum
2201 N Field St
Dallas, TX 75201

Tel : +1 214 428 5555

www.perotmuseum.org

content.title: The Oge House, Scarlett O'Hara style

introduction.small: This property brings back the greatness of a bygone era. Romanticism and authenticity in beautiful harmony, with the river rustling nearby.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Oge House, Scarlett O'Hara style

paragraphs.text:
Need to let the mind wander? The Noble Inn can be your home base, with three distinct and distinguished buildings (The Oge House, Jackson House and Pancoast Carriage House), transformed into Bed & Breakfasts. The Oge House, dating from 1857, is the most remarkable of the three, a magnificent ten-bedroom residence with a neo-Victorian facade and balconies reminiscent of the house in Gone with the Wind. Located in the historic King William district and bordered by the San Antonio River, you could almost forget to explore the famous Riverwalk located nearby. The luxuriousness of the surrounding 6,000 m2 park, the outdoor pool with its majestic trees, the Jacuzzi and the fresh lemonade served on the terrace will make for a perfect southern escape. For a perfect journey back in time, choose the Blenheim suite. With a fireplace, thick curtains and Art Nouveau furniture, it has everything! The Oge River Suite, with its welcoming armchairs and pretty balcony is another room that offers an invitation to daydream.

The Oge house
209 Washington Street
San Antonio, TX 78204

+1 210 223 2353

www.ogeinn.com

Rooms: from 199 USD

content.title: Gung Ho, the creative new American-Asian canteen

introduction.small: On the Dallas culinary scene, this restaurant is making a buzz with its amazing mix of flavours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gung Ho, the creative new American-Asian canteen

paragraphs.text:
Opened in March 2018, this address is the new flagship of fusion cuisine. Enter a long room with blue tones and a bar area with red Chinese tapestries. “Mongolian tablitas” and “Wuxi” nine-spice and rock-sugar glazed pork ribs announce an offbeat tone on the menu. Dishes are flavourful and can be eaten Chinese style: whether a starter or main course, everything is served in the middle of the table to share.
Try the smashed cucumber salad, mixed with coriander, red onion and Chinese sausages. Everyone in town is talking about the “White Cloud Tiger Cry” salad—white and black mushrooms, sesame seeds, small cubes of cucumber, crispy onions and shallots, topped with lemon vinaigrette, a delight for diehard epicureans. Indulge in one of the cocktails that make the establishment famous—to be enjoyed in moderation of course. A visit to Gung Ho will assuredly titillate your taste buds.

Gung Ho
2010 A Greenville Avenue
Dallas, TX 75206

+1 972 910 2106

www.gunghodallas.com

Menu: about 30 USD

content.title: Felix Culpa, new popular cuisine

introduction.small: This trendy spot clearly reaches its objective: serving delicious guilty pleasures. Pop Art settings are a bonus.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Felix Culpa, new popular cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Blue velvet, dark wooden floors, brick walls, a long marble bar, paintings by Roy Liechtenstein, portraits of Audrey Hepburn and Marilyn Monroe, a huge Popeye statue by Jeff Koons... Eclectic, chaotic and brightly coloured, Felix Culpa's decoration creates an atmosphere like no other. By installing authentic works of art and objects, including the gigantic crystal chandelier that illuminates the room, owner Massimiliano Sgarbi aims at conveying an intimate setting. On the food side, chef Nick Amoriello offers modern American cuisine with revisited family favourites: gnocchi, shrimp cocktails, cheeseburgers, beef fillet with marrow butter, horseradish sauce and grilled potatoes, though you can also opt for the very nicely presented burrata salad with pears, ham and honey. You may still have plenty of room for dessert—a cinnamon chocolate leaf on ganache, topped with chocolate mousse, mascarpone cream and an amaretto cookie crumble for instance. Sounds good?

Felix Culpa
3001 North Henderson Avenue
Dallas, TX 75206

+1 214 446 9269

www.felixculpadallas.com

Menu: about 45 USD

content.title: Southfork Ranch, on the trail of the Ewing clan

introduction.small: On the ranch of this Dallas family, the anthem of the cult series takes on its full power.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Southfork Ranch, on the trail of the Ewing clan

paragraphs.text:
The music playing over the opening credits of the show resonate in this place open to the public since 1985, about 40 kilometres north of Dallas. The TV drama was filmed from 1978 to 1991 on this magnificent property, originally the Duncan family's residence. For those who followed the Ewing family's adventures week after week, you will feel like you recognize every corner of the place. Most of the outdoor shots were filmed here: the imposing gate, the long driveway, the majestic main residence, the swimming pool, and the huge yard. You almost expect to see J.R., Sue Ellen or Bobby Ewing walk out the front door! Whether or not you choose the guided tour, you can see the gun that shot J.R. and pose for a photo next to the patriarch's Lincoln Continental. In addition to the pieces inspired by each of the characters, the ranch offers a museum dedicated to the series. A visit to a mythical place to remember the drama of yesteryear.

Southfork Ranch
3700 Hogge Drive
Parker, TX 75002

Tel : +1 972 442 7800

www.southforkranch.com

content.title: Hotel ZaZa, truly extraordinary

introduction.small: With its punchy name, this four-star hotel is one of the most fashionable boutique hotels in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel ZaZa, truly extraordinary

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of the city, Hotel ZaZa subtly brings you elegance, comfort and a certain chic that go hand-in-hand with the “Uptown” neighbourhood in which it is located, only a 20-minute walk from downtown Dallas. Beyond its ochre facade, bedrooms and bungalows, as well as some very spacious concept suites, all offer a truly unique experience. The Bohemia suite, with its intimate and colourful style, invites you to sit back in soft armchairs with patchwork cushions and enjoy an imaginary conversation with French artist Toulouse Lautrec. As for the Renaissance-style The Medusa, it will charm you with its exquisite terrace.
Take a moment at one of the best spas in the city, judiciously named “ZaSpa”, a perfect break after a long day of walking. The charming outdoor pool is a great option too; at night, DJs will liven up the evening. For a more intimate setting, visit the Dragonfly restaurant, which serves refined gastronomic American cuisine.

Hotel ZaZa
2332 Leonard Street
Dallas, TX 75201

+1 214 468 8399

www.hotelzaza.com

Rooms: from 300 USD

content.title: Bullion, a chic brewery all in gold

introduction.small: The new address of starred chef Bruno Davaillon is the talk of the town, thanks to the artistry of his bistronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bullion, a chic brewery all in gold

paragraphs.text:
You will first be struck by the setting: the restaurant is floating like a mezzanine on the ground floor of the 400 Record Building, in the shape of a gold ingot and with gold tile “scales”. Surprising yet logical, since the colour gold here refers to the coat of arms of Claude de Bullion, minister to the King of France Louis XIII. Brass, dark wood, leather and velvet bench seats recall the chic of French restaurants, both relaxed and sophisticated. Chef Bruno Davaillon's objective was to revisit the classics but to make them both lighter and more affordable. He wants his ingredients to stand out and have guests enjoy French food the way he would eat it.
Whether you choose lobster quenelles, buffalo stew, or cassoulet with lobster, the chef offers you the best of bistronomy. Impeccable service with just the right touch—in short, golden cuisine in the heart of Dallas.

Bullion
400 S Record Street
Dallas, TX 75202

+1 972 698 4250

www.bullionrestaurant.com

Menu: about 45 USD

content.title: The Adolphus Hotel, a detour to 19th-century America

introduction.small: The first major hotel in Dallas has been welcoming clientele since 1912 in a German Beaux Arts-style building.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Adolphus Hotel, a detour to 19th-century America

paragraphs.text:
Dallas definitely holds many surprises in store. Just three kilometres from the city centre, this 19th-century skyscraper stands out for its eclecticism, typical of the American Beaux Arts style. Built in 1912 and completely renovated in 2005, this 23-storey giant, which remained the tallest building in Dallas for 31 years, offers 400 rooms with modern decor. For a touch of the past, head to the French-style reception room, sumptuous with gold finishes and ceiling frescoes. The lobby's woodwork, contemporary furniture and fireplace area are all very cosy. For a proper shave, the gentlemen can head to the barber shop, open from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. From the ground floor, where the sublime marble bar will certainly catch your eye, climb to the top of the Adolphus where a rooftop pool and an incredible view of Dallas await you. The Nasher Sculpture Center Museum, a ten-minute walk away, will welcome you for a cultural break. Unless you would rather pay a visit to the Cotton Bowl, the famous American football stadium in Fair Park located nearby.

The Adolphus Hotel
1321 Commerce Street
Dallas, TX 75202

+1 214 742 8200

www.adolphus.com

Rooms: from 289 USD

content.title: Rodeo, a national sport

introduction.small: A lively atmosphere reigns at rodeos, an integral part of the Wild West experience and an American pastime !

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rodeo, a national sport

paragraphs.text:
With a bandana around his neck, jeans covered with “chaps” that protect the legs in style, cowboy boots with spurs and the requisite Stetson hat, the cowboy enters the arena to the crowd's cheers. Here, rodeo is a true passion, half sporting event and half patriotic celebration. Rodeos—from the Spanish word rodear for “to go around”—are composed of rough-stock events like bareback bronc riding, timed competitions and much more. A reminder of the conquest of the West and its iconic cowboys, rodeos often feature bull riding too—one of the most popular events, but also the most dangerous.
The official rodeo season in the country begins in the spring and ends in December at the National Finals Rodeo in Las Vegas. The extravagant Forth Worth Stock Show, as well as the events in San Antonio and Houston are all worth a trip. A once-in-a-lifetime experience !

Fort Worth Stock Show & Rodeo
3400 Burnett-Tandy Drive
Fort Worth, TX 76107
Tel : +1 817 877 2400
www.fwssr.com

San Antonio Stock Show & Rodeo
3201 East Houston Street
San Antonio, TX 78219
Tel : +1 210 225 5851
www.sarodeo.com

Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo
3 NRG Pkwy
Houston, TX 77054
Tel : +1 832.667.1000
www.rodeohouston.com

content.title: The Stockyards Hotel, to relive the folklore of the West

introduction.small: In a Western atmosphere, the best place to stay to enjoy a rodeo.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Stockyards Hotel, to relive the folklore of the West

paragraphs.text:
Walking through the front door, it could be easy to picture a 19th-century cowboy walking down the large wooden staircase towards the bar. This is the atmosphere that the Stockyards Hotel offers in the heart of Fort Worth Stockyards—the historic district from which it takes its name. Using the slogan “The Old West at its best”, this long red brick building indeed takes you back to the days of the Wild West. Although the hotel has been in existence since 1907, it has been restored to its former glory. Simplicity and rusticity are the key words, to which one can add comfort and a welcoming atmosphere—in short all you need to recover from a rodeo! The 52 rooms have evocative names such as “Bonnie & Clyde”, “The Native American” and “Outlaw Mountain”… The “Celebrity Suite” with its sumptuous brick fireplace, adjacent lounge and private patio with a Jacuzzi will indeed make you feel like a star.

The Stockyards Hotel
109 E. Exchange Avenue
Fort Worth TX 76164

+1 800 423 8471

www.stockyardshotel.com

Rooms: from 150 USD

content.title: The Sixth Floor Museum, the last minutes of JFK

introduction.small: The shots fired from this building on 22 November 1963 were allegedly those that killed JFK as the procession drove by.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Sixth Floor Museum, the last minutes of JFK

paragraphs.text:
Lee Harvey Oswald reportedly fired the deadly shots at the 35th American President from the sixth floor of this administrative building. The former Texas School Book Depository stands at the corner of Elm and Houston Streets and is now open to visitors. Thanks to the impressive exhibits consisting of films, photos and other documents, the museum examines the life, death, socio-political context and heritage of JFK. The part of the exhibition entitled “Corner Window” (the window from which the shooter supposedly fired) realistically describes the crime scene: on video screens, a white cross painted on the roadway indicates the exact location where JFK died. “Crisis Hours” follows the intense 48 hours that followed the assassination, while “The Investigations” details various speculations and explains the report presented to Kennedy's successor. The tour ends with “Legacy”, exploring the impact of JFK on the American landscape. The seventh floor holds temporary exhibitions and special programmes about JFK. A tribute and memory museum well worth visiting.

The Sixth Floor Museum
411 Elm Street
Dallas, TX 75202

Tel : +1 214 747 6660

www.jfk.org

content.title: Truck Yard, Texas version of a beer festival

introduction.small: A Texan beer garden complete with food trucks and a motto: “brews, grub, tunes.”

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Truck Yard, Texas version of a beer festival

paragraphs.text:
No fewer than 24 beers on tap! This is the hallmark of this red truck taking up a spot on the immense open-air space, amidst other neon-lit stands and several other food trucks—among the best in Dallas. In the middle of an Art Brut decor, large tables and long wooden benches are set up where you can dine. This huge piece of land, formerly a vacant lot in the Lower Greenville area, has become a trendy landmark in Dallas in just a few years. Under a parasol, near the large open-air bar, order a beer brewed in Texas and chat with your neighbours—conviviality is on the menu. With a cocktail in hand, you will be able to listen to a few notes strummed on a guitar. When you get hungry, nibble on a hamburger, pizza or Cajun dish—different trucks for different tastes!

Truck Yard
5624 Sears Street
Dallas, TX 75206

+1 469 500 0139

www.truckyarddallas.com

Menu: about 10 USD

content.title: NorthPark Center: where shopping meets art

introduction.small: This visionary shopping centre is both an ode to consumption and a temple of art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: NorthPark Center: where shopping meets art

paragraphs.text:
You have just run into Joan Miró, Alexander Calder, Barbara Hepworth, Richard Serra, Donald Judd, Roy Lichtenstein, Anish Kapoor, Richard Deacon, Jeff Koons and others right here in a shopping centre! In 1960, this building was erected on the site of former cotton fields with the objective of presenting the prestigious works collected by Raymond D. Nasher. In the words of this visionary American businessman, real estate magnate and philanthropist, the centre was conceived as an exhibition space: “Each company has a special responsibility to enrich the lives of its customers and the community. It should serve as a catalyst to link art and business for the benefit of all.” Since opening in July 1965, the NorthPark Center has welcomed major American brands and imposed its little revolution. Half a century later, it attracts 26 million visitors a year and is home to the most prestigious international luxury brands (Vuitton, Gucci, Tiffany, Tod's, Ferragamo, Longchamp and as of spring 2019 Saint Laurent), with many more for everyone's budgets. The Art of Shopping !

NorthPark Center
8687 North Central Expressway
Dallas, TX 75225

+1 214 363 7441

www.northparkcenter.com

content.title: A walk on Swiss Avenue, Dallas icon

introduction.small: Four kilometres of shaded streets to admire the 16 architectural styles of the city's 200 most impressive homes—an enticing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A walk on Swiss Avenue, Dallas icon

paragraphs.text:
Erected in Mediterranean, Spanish, Georgian, Neoclassical, Colonial, Tudor, or Italian and English Renaissance styles, with tributes to the Prairie School and the Arts and Crafts movements, the homes lined up here provide you with a rather surprising cultural promenade. Inscribed on the National Register of Historic Places since 1974, the Swiss Avenue Historic District, in the east of Dallas, has nothing Swiss about it other than being named after the arrival of a few Swiss immigrants who settled there around 1905. For all Texans, the residential district that emerged from the ground at the beginning of the 20th century is above all an architectural feast for the eyes. These magnificent residences built throughout the century by bankers, oil magnates, farmers and traders are in as many styles as there were owners. The houses have evolved over the years, and the Bryan Parkway block, a mix of Arts and Crafts cottages and bungalows, is one of the few that has preserved its integrity. Best enjoyed while on “Mother's Day Home Tour”, allowing you to admire the interiors of some houses when open to the public

www.sahd.org

content.title: Contemplating creativity at the Dallas Museum of Art

introduction.small: The city's most prestigious cultural institution also houses a collection of Coco Chanel items.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Contemplating creativity at the Dallas Museum of Art

paragraphs.text:
On this beautiful and informative visit, you can see some 24,000 works covering 5,000 years of human creativity—from the Third millennium BC to the present day. Designed by Edward Larrabee Barnes, winner of the 2007 American Institute of Architects Gold Medal, the museum's American art collection highlights paintings by Edward Hopper and Georgia O'Keeffe. The Spanish colonial art section is impressive as well and make sure you stop by the particularly remarkable German contemporary art section—exhibiting Gerhard Richter, Sigmar Polke and Anselm Kiefer. The Wendy and Emery Reves Collection exhibits more than 1,400 impressionist and postimpressionist paintings, sculptures and drawings that these aesthetes gathered between the 1940s and 1960s. Surprisingly, the institution also displays a collection of objects that belonged to Coco Chanel in a space recreated like the interior of the famous La Pausa villa, former Côte d'Azur home of the French fashion designer.

Dallas Museum of Art
1717 North Harwood Street
Dallas, TX 75201

Tel : +1 214 922 1200

www.dma.org

content.title: Louie King, BBQ with a twist

introduction.small: Opened in late 2018 by a promising young chef, this BBQ restaurant revisits the classics.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Louie King, BBQ with a twist

paragraphs.text:
“Enter if you smell smoke!” That is the message from Will Fleischman, champion of barbecue and smoked meats, who previously worked at the Smoked House Lockart (another must-see BBQ in the city). Your sense of smell will lull you in this restaurant with a neon bull overhead, and your taste buds will ultimately thank you. With its Americana decor, this is the place that everyone in Dallas is talking about—first and foremost due to the personality of the owner. The rising star of the Dallas BBQ scene is indeed providing a cuisine in line with its look: offbeat. On the menu, the Akaushi beef steak is praised by many fans. Do not miss the shaved pork loins: instead of the traditional pulled pork, Will Fleischman offers smoked pork fillets with a herb crust. Macaroni gratins and white beans are also on the menu, in updated versions. As for the famous barbecue sauce, aromatic herbs spice it up. Enjoy the roast, to take out or eat at the counter!

Louie King
1916 Greenville Avenue
Dallas, TX 75206

Tel : +1 214 812 9848

www.louiekingbbq.com

Menu: about 15 USD

content.title: Reunion Tower, Dallas from above

introduction.small: Nicknamed “God's golf ball”, this 171-metre high tower offers a breathtaking view of Dallas, day and night.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Reunion Tower, Dallas from above

paragraphs.text:
Since opening in 1978, this skyscraper has always attracted attention. The 36-metre diameter dome covered with 260 LEDs, supported by a reinforced concrete cylinder, contains an 837-step staircase. Yes, it looks like a golf ball in the sky—hence its nickname. The Reunion Tower is one of Dallas' most recognizable monuments and, never fear, it takes just 68 seconds to reach the top by elevator.
At nightfall, the view of the skyline is breathtaking from the two levels: the first occupied by an observation deck for a close-up examination of the culture, architecture and history of Dallas from the sky (with high-definition zoom cameras, telescopes and interactive touch screens). The second level holds the award-winning, 100-seat Five Sixty gourmet restaurant by Wolfgang Puck. The restaurant turns one complete rotation in 55 minutes: enough to make your head turn! The tower is open every day, but hours vary throughout the year depending on holidays and special events, so be sure to check their site beforehand.

Reunion Tower
300 Reunion Boulevard East
Dallas, TX 75207

Tel : +1 214 712 7040

www.reuniontower.com

content.title: The Joule, breathtakingly modern

introduction.small: “Delicious!” is what you will utter after eating one of the typical Texan dishes served in this modern saloon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Joule, breathtakingly modern

paragraphs.text:
There are many surprises awaiting you here. Hotel Joule is located downtown in a 19-storey neo-Gothic building, the former National Bank of Dallas built in 1927. The reputation of this five-star hotel is propelled by the striking tenth-floor swimming pool, suspended above the void and showcasing a glass wall—a technical and aesthetic feat that sets the tone for more. From the lobby to the 164 rooms—including stunning penthouses decorated with works by Bram Tihany—the clean lines and stunning design will impress you.
Another surprise lies in the collection of paintings and sculptures scattered throughout that gives the appearance of an art gallery. Andy Warhol, Tony Cragg, Adam Fuss and Richard Phillips—only the best adorn the walls. To find the ideal gift to bring back in your suitcase, from designer objects to trendy clothes, just walk through the Joule concept stores: the Hotel Shop by 4510/SIX, the Taschen bookshop or the Traffic Los Angeles and Tenoverix boutiques. Take a break at the spa and fitness room, with a personal trainer if you wish. You may never want to leave The Joule.

The Joule
1530 Main Street
Dallas, TX 75201

+1 214 748 1300

www.thejouledallas.com

Rooms: from 207 USD

content.title: Frontiers of Flight Museum, the pioneers of the sky

introduction.small: Take off to visit this aerospace museum exploring the frontiers of aeronautics.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Frontiers of Flight Museum, the pioneers of the sky

paragraphs.text:
The famous motto, “Higher, faster, farther,” has inspired generations of pilots to go off into the great unknown. Within the walls of this museum, these words resonate, reaffirming a mission to explore space in all its dimensions. Created under the leadership of William E. (Bill) Cooper and Jan Collmer in 1988, the Frontiers of Flight Museum presents the incredible collection of objects and archives of George E. Haddaway, a prominent aviation historian and publisher of Flight magazine. From the parachutes designed by Leonardo da Vinci in 1485 to the first steps of aviation at the beginning of the 20th century and modern space exploration, the path of the museum traces humanity's unfinished conquest. Two-seaters, military aircraft, and airliners are to be found along this tour in life-size models or engineering drawings. If you decide to get on board, don't miss the northern part of the museum, which features a Mustang Aviation hangar from the 1940s.

Frontiers of Flight Museum
6911 Lemmon Avenue
Dallas, TX 75209

Tel : +1 214 350 3600

www.flightmuseum.com

content.title: Dallas Farmers Market, a paradise for healthy eaters

introduction.small: By selling their produce at this market since the 19th century, local farmers have carried on with a culture of what is good and what is right.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dallas Farmers Market, a paradise for healthy eaters

paragraphs.text:
Here you will discover the organic and gourmet side of Dallas! Texas farmers originally came to sell their produce at these crossroads from their own wagons before the municipal market was opened in 1941. Located in the city centre, this agricultural market has remained the meeting place for lovers of quality fresh produce. Today, the 2,500 m2 market sells baked goods, meats, cheeses and produce alongside restaurants, artisan food producers and food stalls offering world cuisine. A few other boutiques are also present, including Urban Farmhouse Designs, award-winning interior design company that opened its second store here very recently. Stop at Mudhen Meat and Greens, famous for its brunch, or at the Palmieri Cafe, which serves a pasticciotto (filled Italian pastry) to die for. Enjoy a coffee while gazing at the Dallas skyline. A culinary stroll for fine gourmets.

Dallas Farmers Market
920 South Harwood Street
Dallas, TX 75201

Tel : +1 214 664 9110

www.dallasfarmersmarket.org

content.title: NYLO, a New York touch in Dallas

introduction.small: Both trendy and a bit rock and roll, this hotel boasts a Big Apple-inspired atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: NYLO, a New York touch in Dallas

paragraphs.text:
With its loft rooms and spacious suites sheltered behind a 1911 facade, the NYLO, located in South West Dallas, is full of character. Respectful of the environment, the 76 rooms and eight suites showcase polished concrete floors and exposed brick walls—reflecting the architectural codes of the facade—plus a high ceiling and, above all, huge picture windows.
This is a haven for trendy young people with a touch of art, light wood furniture and high-tech accessories (flat screens, speakers, coffee makers and connected alarm clocks). Without a doubt, a Brooklyn feel permeates the air. Only the SODA Bar, the rooftop cocktail bar and the outdoor pool, with its breathtaking view of the skyline, will remind you that you are in Dallas. Renowned for its brunch, the Terrace Bistro on the first floor will fill you up before moving on with your day. NYLO is only a short distance from the performance venues of the Cedars District, and from the must-see Alamo Draft House, a cinema with food and drinks service.

NYLO Dallas South Side
1325 South Lamar Street
Dallas, TX 75215

+1 214 421 1080

www.nylohotels.com/dallas

Rooms: from 180 USD

content.title: La Zona, Iberian flavours in Fort Worth

introduction.small: Tapas, cocktails and churros: Fort Worth in Spanish style.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Zona, Iberian flavours in Fort Worth

paragraphs.text:
These two small limewashed store fronts labelled “Hotel Madrid” and “Saint Sofia” are the highlights of West Magnolia Avenue. A little wisp in the air reminds one of Marfa, the western Texas town in the middle of the desert— maybe because of the clay ground surrounding the two buildings. Hotel Madrid, the restaurant-bar with a cosy European atmosphere, will be a nice change of scenery from the cowboy hangouts in the city. The tiled bar attracts quite a crowd at happy hour. Order something to eat as well: boquerones, cheeses or fried squid recall Spain, while wood-fire baked pizzas remind you of the Mediterranean. Feel like churros, coffee or ice cream? Head for the small adjacent building, Saint Sofia, just across the patio bordered with desert plants. The perfect place to observe the comings and goings of the crowd on Magnolia Avenue, while sipping on a sangria or cocktail, in moderation of course.

La Zona
1264 West Magnolia Avenue
Fort Worth, TX 76104

+1 817 489 5055

www.lazonafw.com

Menu: about 20 USD

content.title: Rosewood Mansion on Turtle Creek, the pearl of Dallas hotels

introduction.small: A former mansion, the Rosewood offers the most exclusive, romantic atmosphere in Dallas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rosewood Mansion on Turtle Creek, the pearl of Dallas hotels

paragraphs.text:
Tennessee Williams and President Franklin Roosevelt both stayed here. Since then, the Italian-style building dating from the early 20th century has lost none of its splendour and appeal. This private home, only a stone's throw from the Arts District and seven kilometres from the airport, will make you feel like you have been here before. And that is exactly what Rosewood Mansion on Turtle Creek aspire to with impeccable service, a sophisticated interior, lush gardens, an inviting terrace and a stunning pool and spa... The customer is truly king!
Thanks to extensive restoration work performed in 1980, this famed hotel has managed to preserve the charm of yesteryear with added capacity. The result: 143 rooms, 15 suites and a renowned restaurant with a French chef. Beef fillet with parsnips and leeks and a perfectly stuffed Texas quail are a couple of delicious dishes you can try. Just a few steps outside the hotel, you will enjoy Turtle Creek Park, a haven of greenery in the heart of the city, and a few minutes away, the Fair Park Aquarium awaits your visit, with the promise of wonderful discoveries for young and old alike.

Rosewood Mansion on Turtle Creek
2821 Turtle Creek Boulevard
Dallas, TX 75219

+1 214 559 2100

www.rosewoodhotels.com

Rooms: from 300 USD

content.title: Heywood Hotel, the boutique hotel in Austin

introduction.small: The coolest hotel in Austin? This is it. Chic, modern and offbeat.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Heywood Hotel, the boutique hotel in Austin

paragraphs.text:
Pure lines coexist within an almond green building in this motel-style hotel that recalls the 1950s. With only seven rooms, this ideally located boutique hotel, opened in 2012, has won numerous awards. Vintage and re-arranged furniture, white tiles, natural pine floors… simplicity reigns in an inviting manner. The King Patio, offering a private courtyard, will surprise you with its unique decor and layout. Special mention should be given to the terrace with its wicker chairs and architectural layout.
A plus is that no car is needed as the hotel is located only a few blocks from the city centre, the Convention Center, Rainey Street, Lady Bird Lake and 6th Street. Tailor-made style, character and hospitality, no less.

Heywood Hotel
1609 East Cesar Chavez Street
Austin, Texas 78702

+1 512 271 5522

www.heywoodhotel.com

Rooms: from 200 USD
